Paper title: A healthy debate: Exploring the views of medical doctors on the ethics of artificial intelligence
Authors: Andreia Martinho, Maarten Kroesen, Caspar Chorus
Paper highlights: In this study the authors surveyed medical doctors based in three countries about the ethics surrounding Health AI

Paper title: Ethics and privacy of artificial intelligence: Understandings from bibliometrics
Authors: Yi Zhang, Mengjia Wu, George Yijun Tian, Guangquan Zhang, Jie Lua
Paper highlights: Mapping between 15 AI techniques and 17 major ethical issues is given

Paper title: Ethics of autonomous weapons systems and its applicability to any AI systems
Paper highlights: Dual use of AI implies that tools designed for good be used as weapons and the need to regulate them from that perspective

Paper title: AI research and data protection: Can the same rules apply for commercial and academic research under the GDPR?
Paper highlights: The paper examines how the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is applied to the development of AI products and services, drawing attention to the differences between academic and commercial research

Paper title: A Neo-Republican Critique of AI ethics
Paper highlights: Paper proposes that the neo-republican conception of freedom as non-domination provides a suitable framework to inform responsible ML developmen

Paper title: Creating ethics guidelines for artificial intelligence and big data analytics customers: The case of the consumer European insurance market
Authors: Martin Mullins, Christopher P.Holland, Martin Cunneen
Paper highlights: Analysis of AI in insurance operations regarding customer behavioral data

Paper title: Artificial intelligence: From ethics to law
Paper highlights: Analyses the wide-ranging debate in which there is a growing concern about its ethical and legal aspects

Paper title: Some critical and ethical perspectives on the empirical turn of AI interpretability
Paper highlights: Paper proposes two scenarios for the future development of ethical AI: more external regulation or more liberalization of AI explanations

Paper title: Ethics of artificial intelligence in global health: Explainability, algorithmic bias and trust
Paper highlights: The pathway to a fair, appropriate and relevant AI necessitates the development, and critically, successful implementation of national and international rules and regulations

Paper title: Artificial intelligence for human flourishing – Beyond principles for machine learning
Authors: B.C.Stahl, A.Andreoue, P. Brey, T.Hatzakis,A.Kirichenko,K.Macnish,S.Laulhé Shaelou, A.Patel,M.Ryan,D.Wright
Paper highlights: Governance mechanisms can ensure that AI is conducive to human flourishing
